title: 108_s979
content: The Act is titled the "Broad-Based Stock Option Plan Transparency Act of 2003". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that innovation and entrepreneurship, especially in the high technology industry, drove economic growth in the 1990s and will continue to be crucial in the 21st century. Employee stock option plans help attract quality workers, incentivize innovation, and increase productivity, benefiting shareholders. Broad-based employee stock option plans that involve rank-and-file employees promote capital formation, benefit workers, and improve corporate performance, addressing concerns about their impact on shareholder value. Investors deserve accurate information about employee stock options and their impact on share value. Improved transparency and reporting disclosures for employee stock options. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require companies to disclose detailed information on stock option plans and employee equity arrangements, focusing on the dilutive effects. This includes a plain English discussion and visual aids to illustrate the impact of stock option plans. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require companies to disclose detailed information on stock option plans and employee equity arrangements, focusing on the dilutive effects. This includes expanded disclosure of the dilutive effect of employee stock options on earnings per share, prominent placement of stock option related information, and a summary of stock options granted to top executives. The term "equity interest" encompasses various securities and options to acquire such securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require companies to disclose detailed information on stock option plans and employee equity arrangements, focusing on the dilutive effects. This includes expanded disclosure of the dilutive effect of employee stock options on earnings per share, prominent placement of stock option related information, and a summary of stock options granted to top executives. The term "equity interest" encompasses various securities and options to acquire such securities. SEC. 4. EVALUATION OF EMPLOYEE STOCK OPTION PLANS TRANSPARENCY AND REPORTING DISCLOSURES AND REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a study on the effectiveness of enhanced disclosures for investors and report the results to Congress. Additionally, there will be a moratorium on new accounting standards related to stock options for a specified period. The Commission will not recognize new accounting standards for stock options after 60 days from the report transmission date. SEC. 5. STUDY ON THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF BROAD-BASED EMPLOYEE STOCK OPTION PLANS AND REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on broad-based employee stock option plans, focusing on high technology and high growth industries. The study will examine the impact of these plans on expanding corporate ownership to employees at various income levels, recruitment and retention of skilled workers, stimulating research and innovation, and the economic growth of the United States. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on broad-based employee stock option plans in high technology and high growth industries. The study will analyze the impact of these plans on expanding corporate ownership to employees, recruitment and retention of skilled workers, stimulating innovation, and enhancing the international competitiveness of US companies. A report on the study must be submitted to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate within one year of the Act's enactment.
